description:
A [cha chaan teng](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cha_chaan_teng) classic, emblematic of Hong Kong's Chinese-Western fusion cuisine, this is baked pork chop on a bed of egg fried rice, surrounded by tomato sauce and topped with cheese.

**Personal Note**

I had this frequently in my workplace cafeteria during a stint in Hong Kong, so I was excited to see this on the menu at a restaurant in the US, but when I asked for “baked pork chop on rice” as it was listed on the menu, they said “We don't have baked pork chop on rice.” Then I asked for “jyū pàh faahn” (pork chop rice in Cantonese), and they said OK. So it pays to learn the language.

**Characters**

{焗} is *baked*, {豬扒} is *pork chop* or *pork cutlet*, and {飯} is *rice* (cooked), so 焗豬扒飯 is *baked pork chop rice*.

images.place: Lucky House Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
This fried rice has ketchup and ham, so it's “western,” although it's a product of Hong Kong.

I used to get this dish in Hong Kong food courts because it was relatively easy to pronounce the name, and who doesn't like ham and ketchup? But I had a tough time finding it here in the States.

{西} is *west*, and {炒飯} is *fried rice*.

words.Yale: yìuh chyúh dáan baahk cháau faahn
words.Pinyin: yáo zhù dàn bái chǎo fàn

images.place: JJ Noodle Cafe, Las Vegas, Nevada

description:
[Billionaire fried rice](https://www.wokandkin.com/dried-scallop-and-egg-white-fried-rice/) is named (in English) for a Hong Kong billionaire who wanted a healthy fried rice recipe, and the result is this [fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) mixed with dried scallops and egg whites.

**Characters**

The Chinese name for this dish is more literal: {瑤柱} is *dried scallops*, {蛋白} is *egg white* ({蛋} is *egg*, {白} is *white*), {炒飯} is [fried rice](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_fried_rice) ({炒} is [stir-fried](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir_frying), and {飯} is *rice*), so 瑤柱蛋白炒飯 is *dried scallops and egg white stir-fried rice*.
